item.title: Google Chrome!!
item.dc:creator: dstegelman
item.content:encoded:
Ubuntu users (or users of a Ubuntu-based distro) who have been waiting patiently for the chance to play with Google Chrome, there's now a dead simple way for you to do it. Thanks to the PPA (personal package archive) for Chromium daily builds team, getting the pre-alpha Chromium browser running on your system is about as painless as it can be at this stage. You'll need to add repositories, of course. They are (substitute jaunty or hardy if needed):
deb http://ppa.launchpad.net/chromium-daily/ppa/ubuntu intrepid main deb-src http://ppa.launchpad.net/chromium-daily/ppa/ubuntu intrepid main
Once they've been added, running sudo apt-get install chromium-browser in a terminal window will take care of the rest. After the package has finished installing, just type chromium-browser [enter] to fire it up. While it's still in its early stages, Chromium on Linux runs as it does on Windows - fast and smooth. Some important features aren't working yet, like the tab and bookmarks bars and options menu, but nearly everything else is. Incognito, history, download manager, and the new tab view are all functional, and every web page I tested rendered beautifully - and fast.

item.title: Django Boilerplate
item.dc:creator: dstegelman
item.content:encoded:
Lately, I've been needing a starting place for my django projects, and I've noticed a common pattern.
  • Too many applications floating around that get confused with other module directories.
  • A need for separate urls and settings files for production, testing, and staging.
  • A place to keep custom libraries that aren't shared.
  • Proper inheritance of settings.
  • Api management for apps that need APIs.
  • Reusable fabric files and automation of compression and build scripting.
On top of this one of my reoccuring problems has been the need to look up what should be basic stuff out of the Django docs, ie, how to import render, or how to setup a RSS feed.  What I've started on github, and what I've been working on at work as well is a boiler plate of sorts.  A way to get my projects quickly up to speed by automating and simplifying some redundant tasks.  In the boilerplate you'll find a Django static server, sqlite, and a fabfile already to go.  You'll also notice some libraries that I use a lot, and snippets that I typically need have been complied into a pip installable library on github as well.

item.title: Beer Mayhem
item.dc:creator: dstegelman
item.content:encoded:
So tonight my goal was to bottle my newest brew while brewing a new slightly home edited super heavy that my fellow brew mate and I, like to call the Imperial Bock.
Bottling went fine, took forever, but I tasted what was left of a half filled bottle and it was amazing. ¬†By far the best brew I have made so far. ¬†That took about an hour and half from start to finish.
After that we decided to kill the last all malt extract kit I had laying around the house which just so happened to be a bock. ¬†A bock is a dark German lager that should be fermented around 45 - 55 degrees. ¬†Well, I didn't want to wait till winter for it, so we decided to just go for it now. ¬†In honor of our last beginners kit we decided to change thigns up a bit. ¬†Just before cooling the wort down we added 2.5 pounds of corn sugar. ¬†Essentially, this will add more fermentable sugars to the beer causing it produce much more alcohol. ¬†Thus we have created the Imperial Bock!
I will take some pics and have a review of the Kolsh ¬†once it comes out of bottle fermentation...

item.title: A little about home brewing
item.dc:creator: dstegelman
item.content:encoded:
I thought I'd share some of my experiences and current beers with you today. ¬†I have been on a bit of a binge of brewing lately trying to get beers ready for both this summer and Oktoberfest in September. ¬†My two summer time beers (possibly a third), right now are a Bavarian Witbeir, and an English Pale Ale. ¬†The Oktoberfest beer has already been made and is currently in secondary. ¬†Today I popped open one of my spring beers a Koln Kolsch. The Kolsch has been aging in bottle at cold temperatures (bottle lagering) for about 3 weeks now. ¬†It is perfect for a spring beer. ¬†It has a mellow light mouth feel along with a pop of flower and citrus that reminds you that summer is coming soon. ¬†This has been one of my favorites so far and I am sure I will be brewing this again, either at the end of the summer or again at spring time next year.

A little about Brewing

I wanted to show you a bit about brewing today as well. ¬†In the fermentation cave (our third bedroom of our house) sits both my primary and secondary fermentation vessels. ¬†The one that is dark and on the left is my secondary which is made of glass, and the white bucket to the right is the primary. ¬†The primary contains my Bavarian Witbier which does not require a secondary fermentation due to the desire to have loads of yeast ending up in the finished product. In the secondary lies my German Altbier. ¬†I decided to brew this Altbier for an Oktoberfest beer this year because I did not start early enough this year to lager a proper Marzen. ¬†This winter I will be brewing a Marzen to save and lager for the next year. The primary fermentation takes anywhere between 5 - 14 days, with secondary taking as long as necessary to clear up the beer. ¬†After both (or one) fermentation is complete bottling takes place where I add another batch of corn sugar in order to carbonate the beer. ¬†Carbonation for the witbier is expected to take anywhere between 2 - 8 days. ¬†However, because I put the Altbier through secondary it is expected to take around 2 weeks to carbonate, but because it's my Oktoberfest brew I won't drink this beer until September of this year. ¬†It should pair well with football season.

item.title: Announcing FotoChest
item.dc:creator: dstegelman
item.content:encoded:
Introducing FotoChest

The past few months I have been quietly brewing another new exciting product. ¬†I have long needed an application that can handle my massive amounts of photos, that is fast, stable, and elegant. ¬†I was not happy with the new version of Gallery (open source) ¬†and decided to take it upon my self to solve my own problem. ¬†Today I am proud to announce that I am very close to accomplishing that goal. ¬†Without giving away to much I want to share some of that with you.

Album Management

I have never loved the way most photo applications seem to take your perfectly good photo structure and then apply whatever they feel like to it. ¬†With FotoChest you can have as many parent and child albums as you want. ¬†You can include photos in parent albums or have no child albums. ¬†Its all up to you!

Photo Uploads

I don't know about you, but I have a crap ton of photos. ¬†I needed an app that could upload all of my pictures relativly fast. ¬†I used the great jquery plugin Uploadify to handle up to 50 photos at a time with flash and javascript. ¬†The system then keeps your original and creates a thumbnail from it for various purpsoses on the site.

Speed

When I first tried to use Gallery 3 for my photo solution it was dead slow on my server. ¬†I didn't even have that many pictures uploaded yet (under 1000) and the app was crawling. ¬†It was so slow that I had to find a different solution. ¬†FotoChest is built on Codeigniter and is designed to be fast. ¬†Using thumbnails, pagination, and tighter server integration make FotoChest a much faster solution.

Where Can I Get It?

FotoChest is a closed beta right now, but will be available soon. ¬†Follow FotoChest on Twitter for the latest updates and check out more information on FotoChest.com.

item.title: Custom Codeigniter Helpers
item.dc:creator: dstegelman
item.content:encoded:
* Geek Post * Codeigniter helpers are extremely helpful when developing an app such as FotoChest. ¬†While I was cranking out the views I noticed myself asking for data such as "if a user is logged in" or "jquery here". ¬†You can't use model data inside a controller without explicitly pushing it to the controller. ¬†I needed it in several places, but not enough to push it with a __constrcutor. ¬†To solve it I created a really simple helper that basically executed a model function for isLoggedIn();

Next Thing

In between updating, and marketing FotoChest (which I admit, isn't a top priority right now). ¬†I am developing a Codeigniter based open source defect tracker. ¬†Keeping track of bugs and working on them has always been an important thing in the software development world. ¬†I have used several different tools, but none of them have done "exactly " what I want. ¬†Mantis is ugly, and Unfuddle is good, but not yet what I want exactly. ¬†I have also decided to step out of my comfort zone and learn a new VCS (I use SVN at work and most other projects). ¬†Instead I am going to host this new project on gitHub and learn git. ¬†If you want to follow me and my progress or contribute to this app, follow my repo on GitHub. I'm looking forward to hopefully continuing to develop Codeigniter helpers, libs, and more apps.

item.content:encoded:
Too many times I have seen freeware open source projects start with such vigor and high expectations, only to fail or take enormous amounts of time and money. ¬†Most every time I have seen this happen its blamed on the pure fact that the software itself is free. ¬†These projects don't fail because of lack of funding, but a lack of a clear goal and the people resources behind it. ¬†I want to dive into the open source philosophy for a second and gather my thoughts.

So Ugly...

Typically, not always, but typically, open source projects are plain ugly. ¬†Wordpress may be one exception here, but in general, a lot of the free products have either no designer, or little effort or thought put into their look. ¬†And given, it is maybe not the "most" important thing, but if the whole idea behind your product is to gain more use and a wider audience, neglecting your look and feel will certainly not help you achieve that goal.

Release Early, Release Often, but Keep Releasing

So many open source projects follow these first two and then stop once they get to a "satisfying" part of the project. ¬†Companies that build professional software don't stop, they keep improving, the keep iterating. ¬†Open source needs to follow that as well.

Document, Document, Document.

No explanation needed here I think... These are just a few of my thoughts on where this philosophy is going (or rather should go)

item.title: Deck Project Wrap Up
item.dc:creator: dstegelman
item.content:encoded:
So I thought I would go ahead and wrap up my deck project that I have recently completed.

Planning

Initially we had planned on digging foundations, 9 of them in all to provide a footing for the 16 X 16 foot deck. ¬†That was a lot of work. ¬†Instead we found DeckPlans.com which uses pre-poured concrete foundations instead of digging and pouring your own. ¬†We decided to go the route of buying the pre poured foundations. ¬†Unfortunately, that meant that instead of 9 we would need to buy 32 to fit our project. ¬†In retrospect I think it was a toss up for the amount of work involved. ¬†However, it was easier to setup and being unexperienced, I think it was the way to go for the first time. ¬†My Dad also came down to help with the foundation work.

Building

Building the deck was actually fairly easy. ¬†I went ahead and purchased as much of the supplies at once as I could and had them delivered to our house as we have no truck. ¬†We were able to build fairly quickly, and within 2 days, (about 10 hours a day with 2 people and one day had 3 people) we were ready to start decking. ¬†Lindy left for a work trip the next week and I had completed all joists, and decking by the time she got back on Friday! So there, the deck that we built in under a week is done. ¬†Sadly its time for winter here in Kansas which means we'll have to wait till next spring to really enjoy the new deck.

item.title: Django-Piston RSS Emitter
item.dc:creator: dstegelman
item.content:encoded: I recently had the need to push data to Django-Piston in RSS format.  A little background: I had been developing an API with django piston emitting json and xml objects which was great, our project owner requested that these also be emitted in RSS format.  This could be completed right out of the box with django's syndication framework and ignoring piston all together.  The challenge with this, is my API currently supports passing in loads of parameters to query exactly the information desired.  Implementing a solution with the syndication framework means I would need to replicate all my logic and duplicate it accross numerous classes and methods.  To avoid this issue I created a custom emitter that expells RSS formatted data.  I have open sourced the code on github.  I would love any and all feedback to make this thing better.

item.title: Install Django Development Environment on Ubuntu - Virtual Box
item.dc:creator: dstegelman
item.content:encoded:
After spending hours trying to collect these various bits of info, I wanted to post about the details of how to set this up. What I'm Using:
  • VirtualBox 4.0.10
  • Ubuntu 11.04 Server 64 bit
  • mod_wsgi
First thing is to install virtual box on your host machine and configure and boot your server image.  When setting this up I opted to install openSSH server and LAMP server.  We aren't going to use PHP , buts its nice to get Apache and MySQL setup out of the box.  Ideally, you'll want to use Postgres, but my production environment uses MySQL so I want this to mimick it exactly. First, lets update sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get upgrade Install mod_wsgi sudo apt-get install libapache2-mod-wsgi Install pip sudo apt-get install python-pip Install virtualenv pip install --upgrade virtualenv virtualenv newsite --no-site-packages Create a place to place the apps.  This can be wherever sudo mkdir /srv/www/webapps Add host entries to point to your server, also make sure the networking setting in VirtualBox is set to bridged. 10.0.0.1 awesome (Awesome is the name of my server) Create new Apache site sudo vi /etc/apache2/sites-available/newsite Add This Content 
<VirtualHost *:80>

    ServerName wsgi.djangoserver
    DocumentRoot /srv/www/wsgi

    <Directory /srv/www/wsgi>
        Order allow,deny
        Allow from all
    </Directory>

    WSGIScriptAlias / /srv/www/wsgi/app.wsgi

</VirtualHost>
Activate site sudo a2ensite newsite sudo /etc/init.d/apache2 reload Add your wsgi file and follow these suggestions: import os, sys, site sys.path.append('/var/www/webapps/newsite') site.addsitedir('/var/www/.virtualenvs/newsite/lib/python2.7/site-packages') os.environ['DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE'] = 'settings.local' from django.core.handlers.wsgi import WSGIHandler application = WSGIHandler() Install mysql libs sudo apt-get build-dep python-mysqldb pip install MySQL-python

item.title: Who's in My Data?
item.dc:creator: dstegelman
item.content:encoded:
As a part of our projects at OME we like to develop APIs and keep access to our public data as easy as possible.  Recently we've wanted to open up some of our APIs to allow others to add and modify that data.  From the start we picked up django-piston to roll our APIs and have had great success.  As we desire to open up that data and allow create/update/delete access, we needed an authentication solution.

Authentication

Django-Piston comes with HTTP authentication out of the box, but we wanted a bit more control in terms of keeping track of API usage. Instead of using this authentication method we created a django app that we can use to issue API keys and keep track of their usage. While still in its infancy, this tool will be used to manage and authenticate users to our APIs.

Installation

We've compiled the app as a pip installable app, so to install simply:

pip install git+git://github.com/kstateome/api-management.git

Usage

Method Helpers

key_exists(dictionary) - Checks for a key.  Returns true if key exists or false is not

        dictionary is {'key': key}

key_check(dictionary) - Makes sure key is correct.  If key is valid returns True

Example

attrs = self.flatten_dict(request.PUT)
key_dict = {'key': request.GET.get('key')}
        if key_exists(key_dict) == False:
            return key_required_error()
        if key_check(key_dict):
            try:
                audience = Audience.objects.active().get(pk=audience_id)
            except Audience.DoesNotExist:
                return rc.NOT_FOUND
            audience.name = attrs['name']
            audience.save()
            log_use(request.GET.get('key'), 'Audience', audience.id, 'updated')
            return audience
        else:
            return key_incorrect_error()

Logging Helper

log_use(key, object being manipulated as string, id of object, action as string)
Example

log_use(request.GET.get('key'), 'Audience', audience.id, 'updated')

Error Reporting

key_required_error()

    - Error for api required

def key_incorrect_error()

    - Error for api incorrect.

CSRF Protection

Django comes with built in CSRF protection for all POST requests. Because of this by default POST HTTP headers will be rejected for not containing a valid CSRF token. In order to bypass this, API-Management has a helper method to use instead of the default django-piston resource.

Method

CsrfExemptResource(Resource)

Example

CsrfExemptResource(ScholarshipsHandler)

Documentation

I haven't gotten the docs fully written yet but there is some info along with the repo at https://github.com/kstateome/api-management. I will be working on the docs and getting them up as soon as possible. Any suggestions or contributions on our github page are more than welcome.

item.title: Snippet Sunday - Require Login Middleware
item.dc:creator: dstegelman
item.content:encoded:
I recently had to secure an entire site under authentication. Adding @login_required to all views seemed like a terrible idea. Naturally, the Django community pulled through and provided me with an awesome direction. Below is a snippet of middleware I found to secure each and every request coming from the django server. One caveat to note is that if you are using static file hosting through the django app in a development environment, those static files won't be delivered until you login. One small, and manageable problem. Enjoy! 
from django.conf import settings
from django.contrib.auth.views import login
from django.http import HttpResponseRedirect

class RequireLoginMiddleware(object):
    """
    Require Login middleware. If enabled, each Django-powered page will
    require authentication.

    If an anonymous user requests a page, he/she is redirected to the login
    page set by REQUIRE_LOGIN_PATH or /accounts/login/ by default.
    """
    def __init__(self):
        self.require_login_path = getattr(settings, 'REQUIRE_LOGIN_PATH', '/accounts/login/')

    def process_request(self, request):
        if request.path != self.require_login_path and request.user.is_anonymous():
            if request.POST:
                return login(request)
            else:
                return HttpResponseRedirect('%s?next=%s' % (self.require_login_path, request.path))
